title: Protocol for purification and identification of MHC class I immunopeptidome from cancer cell lines
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Generation of MHC immunoaffinity column
Timing: 3 h
The following steps describe the preparation of an immunoaffinity column for MHC class I pull-down.
Note: Wash the glass column with 1% TFA before packing the column for the first time to ensure no contamination from the glass column comes into the antibody-Sepharose column or in pre-column packed with Sepharose beads only.
Transfer the required amount of protein A Sepharose to a 15 mL Falcon tube and wash the beads three times with 10 mL PBS.
Note: Conjugate 10–20 mg of W6/32 antibody per mL of protein A Sepharose beads.
Dilute the antibody solution to a concentration of 0.5–2 mg/mL in PBS.
Retain an aliquot of 5 μL of antibody solution and label it as pre-mAb.
Add antibody to protein A Sepharose beads. Rotate gently end-over-end at 20°C–25°C for 1 h to allow binding.
Transfer the antibody-bound Sepharose beads to a glass column.
Collect the flow through in a fresh tube.
Retain 5 μL of this flow through and label as post-mAb.
Wash antibody-bound Sepharose beads with 10 c.v. of borate wash buffer at 20°C–25°C.
Wash antibody-bound Sepharose beads with 10 c.v. of 0.2 M triethanolamine, pH 8.2, at 20°C–25°C.
Add 4–5 c.v. of freshly prepared 40 mM DMP cross-linker to the column and let it pass through until only a small meniscus is left at the top of the Sepharose beads. Allow the reaction to proceed at 20°C–25°C for 1 h.
Wash the antibody-bound Sepharose beads with 10 c.v. of ice-cold 0.2 M Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, at 20°C–25°C.
Wash the antibody-bound Sepharose beads with 10 c.v. of 0.1 M citrate buffer, pH 3. at 20°C–25°C.
Wash the antibody-bound Sepharose beads with 10 c.v. of PBS, at 20°C–25°C.

Run an SDS-PAGE for the samples aliquoted at steps 2 and 5. Both the heavy chain and light chain bands should be present in the pre-mAb sample and absent in post-mAb.
Troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1]
Critical: Maintaining the pH of triethanolamine at 8.2 is important.
Pause Point: The antibody column can be stored at 4°C for 2–3 months in the presence of 0.02% sodium azide/PBS
Preparation of Sepharose protein A column for pre-clearing of cell lysate
Timing: 3 h
This section describes the steps to make a column for pre-clearing the lysate before IP.
Transfer 1 mL protein A Sepharose beads to glass column.
Wash the column with 10 c.v. of PBS.
Note: The pre-column can be used 10 times or till the column gets blocked.
Pause Point: This column can be stored at 4°C for 2–3 months in the presence of 0.02% sodium azide/PBS.
Preparation of cell lysate
Timing: 3 h
This section describes steps involved in preparation of cell lysate.
Add 2 mL cell lysis buffer (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]) for 100 M cells and let it thaw on ice.
table:files/protocols_protocol_517_1.csv
Homogenize the sample using 18G × 38mm needle. Repeat this 4–5 times in 15 min intervals.
Centrifuge the lysate at 2,000 × g at 4°C for 10 min.
Transfer the supernatant to a fresh tube and centrifuge it at 20,000 × g for 60 min at 4°C.
Pass the supernatant obtained in step 18 through a 0.45 μm filter to remove any debris and aliquot 30 μg equivalent cell lysate in a microcentrifuge tube and label it as pre-IP.
Note: Lysis of cells should be performed at 4°C. Do not store the cell lysate for more than 12 h as proteins tend to aggregate. Best practice is to lyse the cells and immediately carry out immunoprecipitation

Optional: Combine the pellets obtained in steps 17 and 18. Add 2% SDS/50 mM TEABC, pH 8.0 to lyse the membrane bound organelles obtained. Sonicate and centrifuge it at 20,000 × g for 30 min at 4°C. Perform western blot on the lysate obtained after adding 2% SDS/50 mM TEABC and at step 19, using anti-MHC class I antibody. MHC class I band corresponding to 40 kDa should be in the lysate from step 19 while it should be absent in the cell lysate obtained with SDS.
Immunoprecipitation of MHC class-I complex
Timing: 2–3 h
This section describes steps for carrying out immunoprecipitation of MHC class I complex from cell lysate
Note: Same approach can be used for carrying out immunoprecipitation of MHC class I complex from tissue lysate
Pass 10 c.v. of PBS through protein A Sepharose pre-column to remove sodium azide.
Pass cell lysate obtained in step 19 through the pre-column.
Collect flow through in a fresh tube.
Pass 10 c.v. of PBS through the antibody column to remove sodium azide.
Pass 5 c.v. of cell lysis buffer (without detergent) through the antibody column.
Pass the pre-cleared cell lysate obtained in step 22 through the antibody column and collect flow through in a fresh tube.
Pass flow through obtained in step 25 through the antibody column.
Collect flow through in a fresh tube.
Aliquot 30 μg of flow through to a microcentrifuge tube and label it as post-IP.
Wash antibody column with 10 c.v. of cell lysis buffer (without detergent).
Wash antibody column with 10 c.v. of 50 mM Tris, pH 8.0, and 150 mM NaCl.
Wash antibody column with 10 c.v. of 50 mM Tris, pH 8.0, 450 mM NaCl.
Wash antibody column with 10 c.v. of 50 mM Tris, pH 8.0, and 150 mM NaCl.

Wash antibody column with 10 c.v. of 50 mM Tris, pH 8.0.
Elute the proteins bound on antibody column with 10% (v/v) acetic acid in 10 fractions of 500 μL each.
Note: Regenerate the column by passing 10 c.v. of 100 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0 and then 10 c.v. of PBS. The pH of liquid flowing out from the column should be more than 7.
Pool all fractions collected in step 32.
Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3]
Pause Point: The samples can be stored for a couple of days without much loss.
Note: Clear the protein from pre-column by washing the column with 5 c.v. of 10% acetic acid and regenerate by passing 10 c.v. of 100 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0 followed by 10 c.v. of PBS. The pH of liquid flowing out from the column should be more than 7. If reusing pre-column, ensure no protein is left on the column by running later fractions of acid wash on SDS-PAGE. Flow through can be run on SDS-PAGE to ensure no protein is bound to pre-column to avoid cross contamination.
Optional: Perform western blot for the samples labeled pre- and post-IP using anti-HLA-A/B/C antibody. 40 kDa band should be detectable in pre-IP sample and absent in post-IP sample
Purification of peptides from MHC- class I complex by reverse phase liquid chromatography
Timing: 1–3 h
This section describes the steps and parameters for purifying peptides from MHC complex.
Set the flow rate of HPLC system to 2 mL/min (Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2]).
table:files/protocols_protocol_517_2.csv
Equilibrate the column with 2% Solvent B.
Add trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) to the sample obtained at step 33 such that the final concentration of TFA is 1%.
Transfer the eluate to auto sampler vial.
Resolve peptides using the following LC gradient:
table:files/protocols_protocol_517_3.csv
Collect 500 μL fractions in micro centrifuge tubes.

Concatenate the fractions into 6 samples by combining fractions eluted at different hydrophobicity range (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/517-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Separation of peptides from proteins using high performance liquid chromatography
Concentrate the samples using speedvac.
Note: Use protein low bind tubes to concentrate samples. Do not dry the samples completely. Concentrate the samples to 5–10 μL
Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5]
Pause Point: Samples can be stored after this step at −80°C
Mass spectrometry analysis of peptides eluted from MHC complex
Timing: 1 day
This section describes the parameters to be used to acquire data on a Thermo Scientific Orbitrap Fusion mass spectrometer paired with a Waters nanoAcquity UHPLC.
Centrifuge the samples at 15,000 × g for 15 min.
Transfer the samples to total recovery glass vials or 96-well plate compatible with the LC connected to mass spectrometer.
Set nanoLC flow rate to 300 nL/min (Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3]).
table:files/protocols_protocol_517_4.csv
Load the peptides on trap column at 5 μL /min using 5% solvent B.
Resolve peptides on analytical column using the following gradient:
table:files/protocols_protocol_517_5.csv
Acquire mass spectrometry data using following parameters:
MS1: Resolution – 60,000; Mass Range – 350–1,800 m/z; AGC Target – 1e6, Maximum injection time 50 ms.
Precursor selection: Top-speed mode with 2 s cycle time (for top N mode, set N = 10), Include charge state – 1–4; Dynamic exclusion – 5 s
MS2: Isolation window – 1.2 m/z; Activation type – HCD, Collision energy mode – Stepped; HCD Collision Energy – 25,27,30; Orbitrap resolution – 15,000; AGC target – 2e5, Maximum injection time – 120 ms
Note: Data acquisition parameters vary based on the instrument on which data is acquired. The above parameters are for Orbitrap Fusion mass spectrometer
Database searches of mass spectrometry data
Timing: 3 h to 2 days

This section describes mass spectrometry data analysis using Proteome Discoverer suite 2.2 with Sequest/Mascot as search engine
Select spectra based on following parameters: Lowest charge state – 1; Highest charge state – 4; Minimum precursor mass – 350 Da; maximum precursor mass – 5,000 Da
Sequest/Mascot search parameters:
Database: Reference protein database of relevant species.
Note: Add cRAP protein sequences (common Repository of Adventitious Proteins) that are commonly found as contaminant proteins in a proteomics experiment
Enzyme Name: No-Enzyme (Unspecific) on SequestHT, NoCleave on Mascot
Precursor Mass tolerance: 10 ppm
Fragment mass tolerance: 0.05 Da
Dynamic modifications: Oxidation on Methionine, Carbamidomethylation on C
1% FDR at PSM and Peptide level
Note: For identifying MHC peptides with post translational modifications like phosphorylation at S/T/Y, deamidation at N/Q/R can be given as variable modifications for MS/MS search.
Troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7]
Troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9]
Optional: Other MS/MS search algorithms like Peaks and MaxQuant (Cox and Mann, 2008[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]) can also be used. If carrying out mutant/non-canonical peptide analysis, include relevant protein sequences along with reference protein database in step 49a.
Data analysis and interpretation
Timing: 0.5–24 h
This step describes downstream analysis of MHC peptides
Remove peptides originating from known contaminant proteins to get the list of MHC presented peptides.
Carry out sequence length analysis of peptides. Majority of peptides should be between 8 to 14 amino acids.
Motif analysis can be done using tools such as Seq2Logo 2.0 (Thomson and Nielsen, 2012[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]), SYEPEITHI (Schuler et al., 2007[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4])
NetMHCpan-4.1 (Reynisson et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]) can be used to predict the binding affinity of peptides to MHC class I molecule.
Note: For many cancer cell lines, HLA allele information can be found at Cellosaurus, ATCC website, or HLA typing can be performed for the cell lines.
